critical_instructions.item: Analyze ONLY the final image provided for analysis. NEVER analyze any of the example images provided earlier.
Absence of LaTeX formulas is a valid and expected outcome. Do not force identification if no formulas are present.
When in doubt, do NOT classify an element as a LaTeX formula. Accuracy is more important than comprehensiveness.
NEVER classify regular text or non-mathematical symbols as LaTeX formulas, even if they contain numbers or simple operators.
LaTeX formulas must contain mathematical notation, symbols, or complex expressions beyond basic arithmetic.

latex_formula_definition.item: A LaTeX formula is a mathematical or scientific expression written using LaTeX syntax.
LaTeX formulas can be inline (within text) or display (on separate lines).
LaTeX formulas often contain Greek letters, mathematical symbols, and specialized notation.
Formulas may include fractions, integrals, summations, matrices, and other complex mathematical structures.
LaTeX code typically includes commands that start with a backslash (\) and may use curly braces {} for grouping.

not_latex_formulas.item: Simple arithmetic expressions without LaTeX syntax are NOT LaTeX formulas.
Text containing isolated mathematical symbols or numbers is NOT a LaTeX formula.
Chemical formulas or equations without LaTeX syntax are NOT LaTeX formulas.
Citations or reference numbers are NOT LaTeX formulas.
Any content that lacks specific LaTeX syntax or commands is NOT a LaTeX formula.

decision_process.item: Follow the two-step verification process defined in the latex_verification_process.xml file.
In the first pass, identify all potential LaTeX formula structures.
In the second pass, rigorously verify each potential formula against the defined criteria.
Consider the context around each potential formula to avoid misclassification.
For verified formulas, ensure you capture the full LaTeX code, including all commands and syntax.
